value: — the capital and largest city is an important naval base and has a large sea port which remains ice free year round; the world's largest city north of the Arctic Circle
— a large town with the world's northernmost botanical gardens and a ski resort
— the peninsula's oldest town boasts its original fort, the Cathedral of the Assumption (the first stone building in the region), and a museum of local culture
— a closed town, one of the region's oldest, on the Murmansk Fjord; currently a site for decommissioning nuclear Soviet and Russian submarines
— a closed city, the region's second largest city, and the main administrative center of the Russian Northern Fleet

Murmansk Oblast is of interest to a tourist mostly for its novelty value—it is located in Russia's extreme north, above the Arctic Circle, and is relatively easy to get to from

. The highlights of a Murmansk Oblast trip are certainly the capital itself and perhaps also an adventurous trip out to Kola. To heighten the novelty value of your trip, try to come around the summer Equinox, when the sun moves around the sky but never sets, or the winter Solstice, when the sun never rises and the city is plunged into blackness. The winter is cold, but it is also the best time to see the
The easiest way to get in is via Murmansk's airport, which serves flights to/from

. Also from northern Norway and seasonally from Helsinki in Finland.

There is also a long (about 28 hour) daily overnight train to Murmansk from
, which leaves Piter around 18:00 and arrives the next day around 22:00. Trains also travel between Murmansk and

.

From Finland take the overnight train about 19 from
, get a bus with transfer in

and be in Murmansk 23:50 or 24:50 (depending on time zone difference), likewise after some 28 hours.

There are roads with border crossings, from Kirkenes in Norway, and Ivalo in Finland.
